content: The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, includes an amendment regarding an interagency committee on dam safety. SEC. 2 amends Section 7(b) by focusing on Federal programs and coordination among Federal agencies for dam safety. Section 8(a)(3) is amended to replace references to specific plans with a strategic plan. Section 8(b) now requires the Director to prepare a strategic plan to enhance dam safety in the United States. The Director is mandated to prepare a strategic plan to improve dam safety in the United States, establish cooperation with governmental entities, and develop technical assistance materials. The Director is required to develop technical assistance materials, seminars, and guidelines to enhance dam security in the United States. Additionally, the Director will chair the Board to coordinate national efforts to improve dam safety in the country. The Director will chair the Board to coordinate national efforts to improve dam safety in the United States, as outlined in the implementation plan for dam safety training. Amendments are made to sections 8 and 2 of the U.S. Code to reflect these changes. Amendments are made to sections 2 and 8 of the U.S. Code, changing references from section 8(h) to 8(f) and from section 8(f) to 8(e). Section 8(e) is amended to provide assistance to States for establishing dam safety programs. In section 8 of the U.S. Code, amendments are made to provide assistance to States for establishing dam safety programs. The Director shall provide assistance with amounts made available under section 13 to assist States in improving dam safety programs. Amendments are made to provide assistance to States for establishing dam safety programs. Changes include removing certain requirements for State eligibility and replacing "contract" with "agreement" throughout the text. Amendments are made to improve security and revise operating procedures for dam safety programs. The term "contract" is replaced with "agreement" throughout the text. The Director shall establish a committee to monitor dam safety in the United States and advise on national dam safety policy. Voting membership is amended to include 11 voting members. The voting membership of the committee monitoring dam safety in the United States is amended to include 11 voting members, with 5 members selected from State dam safety officials and 1 member representing the private sector. Nonvoting membership and duties are also addressed in the amendments. The voting membership of the committee monitoring dam safety in the United States is amended to include 11 members, with 5 from State dam safety officials and 1 from the private sector. Nonvoting membership may include a representative from the National Laboratories of the Department of Energy. The Board overseeing dam safety in the United States may include nonvoting members such as representatives from Federal or State agencies and dam safety experts. Their duties involve promoting effective programs and policies to enhance dam safety nationwide. The Board oversees dam safety in the United States by establishing and maintaining effective programs, policies, and guidelines to protect human life and property. It encourages coordination and information exchange among Federal and State dam safety agencies to address common issues related to dam safety. The Director may establish work groups under the Board to assist in achieving dam safety goals, which may include planning, design, construction, operation, emergency action planning, inspections, maintenance, regulation, technical or financial assistance, research, and data management. Travel expenses for the Board are also addressed in the amendment. The Director may establish work groups under the Board to assist in achieving dam safety goals, including various activities. Travel expenses for Board members representing federal agencies will be reimbursed from agency appropriations. Each member of the Board representing a Federal agency will be reimbursed for travel expenses, including per diem, at rates authorized for agency employees. Members representing State agencies, the private sector, and work groups may also be reimbursed if funds are available in advance. Each member of the Board representing a State agency, the private sector, and work groups may be reimbursed for travel expenses by FEMA, including per diem, at authorized rates while performing services for the Board. SEC. 4. RESEARCH. Section 9(a) (33 U.S.C. 467g) is amended to include cooperation with the Board, support for development, maintenance of information resources systems for dam safety management, and initiatives for effective public guidance. DAM SAFETY TRAINING. The Act is amended to provide training for State dam safety staff and inspectors upon request. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Section 11 is amended by removing subsection (a) and following text. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 13(a)(1) is amended to increase annual amounts to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Section 13(a)(2) is amended to reallocate funds and update references. (c) Research; Dam Safety Training; Staff.--Section 13 is amended to authorize $1,500,000 for research under section 9 annually from 2003 to 2006. Section 13 authorizes $1,500,000 for research under section 9 annually from 2003 to 2006, along with $500,000 for dam safety training and $600,000 for additional staff for FEMA.
